Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Four Corners Undergraduate STEM Success (FOCUSS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Four Corners STEM Success (FOCUSS) is a collaborative project between Fort Lewis College (a four-year public liberal arts college in Durango, Colorado) and San Juan College (a two-year community college in Farmington, New Mexico), designed to increase the number of students in the Four Corners area who graduate with STEM degrees. San Juan College and Fort Lewis College are geographically close to one another (51 miles apart) and attract many of their students from the same region (western Colorado, northwestern New Mexico, and adjacent parts of Arizona and Utah). Furthermore, Fort Lewis College, which has a tuition waiver for all Native American students, is an excellent transfer destination for the large number of Native American students at San Juan College.

Intellectual Merit. The project consists of four activities: (1) a joint seminar series that brings career-oriented speakers to both institutions; (2) visits by Fort Lewis College STEM faculty and students to San Juan College, to encourage students at San Juan College to continue their education by transferring to Fort Lewis College; (3) an early undergraduate research program run jointly by both institutions; and (4) a tutor/mentor program for Fort Lewis College sophomores and new transfer students, designed to improve retention between first-year courses and upper-level courses at Fort Lewis College. These activities complement existing programs aimed at retaining first-year students and providing support to Native American and Hispanic students at both institutions, and providing undergraduate research experiences to junior and senior STEM majors at Fort Lewis College.

Broader Impact. The project is increasing the number of STEM students who continue from San Juan College to four-year programs, and is increasing the number of STEM majors who graduate from Fort Lewis College. At the same time, the project is increasing the number of underrepresented minorities who graduate with STEM degrees because both San Juan College and Fort Lewis College are designated Native American-Serving, Non-Tribal Institutions by the Department of Education, and serve student bodies that are 27% and 20% Native American, respectively.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Four Corners STEM Success (FOCUSS) was a collaboration between Fort Lewis College (a four-year public liberal arts college in Durango, Colorado) and San Juan College (a two-year college in Farmington, New Mexico). Like other NSF-STEP projects, our goal was to increase the number of students who graduate with bachelors’ degrees in science, technology, engineering, and math. Our project approached this problem through (1) a summer research experience shared by students at both institutions, and (2) tutors embedded in freshmen and sophomore science and engineering labs.

Freshmen and sophomores majoring in Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, Geology, Math, and Physics participated in summer research projects from 2012-2016. Out of the 26 Fort Lewis College students in the program, 25 continued as STEM majors at Fort Lewis College after their research experience. After graduating from Fort Lewis, some of these students have gone on to graduate school; others have started local businesses making use of their science and engineering degrees. For these students, the FOCUSS summer research project gave them their first taste of working as a scientist, and made them want to continue.

The embedded tutor program began with eight tutors per semester helping in freshmen and sophomore courses in Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, Geology, and Physics. The program expanded during the five and half years of the tutor program, until 25 students were hired as tutors in Fall 2016. The results of the program were remarkable. At Fort Lewis College, only 60% of freshmen (with any major) typically continue to their sophomore year. However, students in courses with embedded tutors not only returned to Fort Lewis, but returned as STEM majors. In freshmen courses, 77% to 90% of students in the program returned as STEM majors the following semester. In sophomore courses, 84% to 94% of students in the program returned as STEM majors.

The outcomes of students who attended tutoring sessions was similarly impressive. Students who received tutoring remained at Fort Lewis College at higher rates than students who did not receive tutoring (71% for freshmen, compared to 62% of freshmen who did not receive tutoring; 81% of sophomores, compared to 77% of sophomores who did not receive tutoring). The results of this program convinced the college administration to adapt this model for tutoring campus-wide. Now, after the end of the grant, the college pays junior and senior STEM majors to help in freshmen and sophomore lab courses, both during lab time and as tutors.

By the end of the program in August 2017, the number of students graduating each year with degrees in Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, Geology, Math, or Physics increased from 91 to 137 – an increase of over 50%.

The intellectual merit of the program is that it increased the number of science, technology, engineering, and math majors who graduated from Fort Lewis College. Those goals were accomplished by increasing retention of freshmen and sophomores in science and engineering majors and by providing opportunities to do cutting-edge research early in their academic careers. The broader impact of the project is that those graduates have already contributed to the local economy by creating new businesses using science and engineering skills. The students in these programs include large numbers of Hispanic and Native American students, who are typically underrepresented in STEM disciplines.
